instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMC_WIFI_PWR_EN: What is SMC_WIFI_PWR_EN? SMC_WIFI_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on power to the wifi circuit when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.AP_RESET_L: What is AP_RESET_L? AP_RESET_L resets the wifi hardware when it is low, which will keep it from working. AP_RESET_L needs to be high for reset to not be asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no wifi.

I already replace the wifi card, the wifi PCB and the cable, but with the same result.

On <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>, I have 3.3V on <SIGNAL>SMC_WIFI_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, and on J9510 I also have 3.3V.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>AP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>.
Is the Wifi recognized in system report?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,
It was not recognized in system report.
<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> = 2.8V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> = 2.8V"
This isn't good.
Check pin 22 of J9510 if good soldered.
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> must go down when Wifi is inserted.
Check this line on the RIO board/flex, until the airport card.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
HI,
I already replaced RIO board/flex, but the same result.
J9510 seams to be well soldered, no pins lose, and no signs of corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Clock request line MUST go low, when airport card is inserted.
If not, PCH will not release its PCIE clock signal.
Did you also try another airport card?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
I'm sorry! I was measuring it without the RIO Flex connected.
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> is 0.0012V with RIO board/flex/card connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: Check L9501 and <CAPACITOR>C9532</CAPACITOR>/33.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,
L9501 (readings compared to other one) and <CAPACITOR>C9532</CAPACITOR>/33 seams to be ok.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Did you check coils continuity and also diode mode to ground?
Then you must have bad PCH, or broken trace to it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
I have continuity, and I get 0.333 on diode readings on L9501.
Do you think that its CPU? Is there any way that I can measured it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: If you discarded RIO board/flex and airport card, the only things to check on the board are the two caps and coils on data lines.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,
Sorry to ask, but the only coil that i can see is L9501. On  L9501 I get on <SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_AP_P</SIGNAL> 0,397V. Is this a normal value?
Is there any other coils tthat i can check??

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Yeah, I used plural being dual coil.

Do you get 100MHz clock at L9501?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,
Yes. I have 100MHz on L9501

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: Check if the clock appears at airport connecotr (on RIO) board too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,
I don't have the boardview or schematics for the RIO board. Where can I mesure the clock on RIO? Do you have schematics and board view that can please share?
Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: Airport connector is the same; use any schematic with wireless connected onboard.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Hi,

I think that i measured it correctly.
On <SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_AP_CONN_N</SIGNAL>/P airport connector pins, I get 99~100 MHz

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: Also check the reset signal at same airport connector, on the RIO board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: Yes, i have a signal on <SIGNAL>AP_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> pin

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message:
Then PCH problem; if you are sure MLB connector is good.

Just in case, check if Apple has some update referred to this issue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no wifi
threads.message: OK. I will. Tks!
